abstract.p: We present a case of bilateral renal artery dissection, with the related computed tomographic images, caused by blunt torso trauma. Discussion includes the etiologies of this type of injury, the diagnostic modalities, and treatment options.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Renal vascular injuries are uncommon with a reported incidence of 0.05–0.08% after blunt abdominal trauma (Bruce et al., 2001; Sangthong et al., 2006); bilateral renal artery dissections even more so, with less than 20 cases reported in the literature. Rapid decelerations are the most common mechanism causing this injury and associated injuries are very common (Lopera et al., 2011). Computed tomography (CT) imaging with intravenous contrast is the recommended diagnostic modality. Surgical revascularization or endovascular stenting are treatment options but rapid recognition and treatment is associated with improved outcomes (Dobrilovic et al., 2001; Lee and White, 2002).

sec.title: Case presentation
sec.p:
A previously healthy 24-year-old man was struck by a motor vehicle while changing his tyre. On arrival in the Emergency Department, he was hypotensive and appeared to be in Class III–IV hemorrhagic shock. There was an obvious extensive soft tissue defect of the back with several posterior ribs and vertebral spinous processes visible; open fractures of the left tibia and fibula were also present. After bedside ultrasonography demonstrated fluid in his pelvis, he was taken for emergent laparotomy where a splenic injury was found and treated by splenorrhaphy. While in the operating theater, he had debridement, irrigation, and repair of the large soft-tissue injury on his back by direct closure with placement of three drains; total operative time was 140 minutes. Postoperatively he underwent CT imaging which revealed a subdural hematoma, lung contusions with several rib fractures and right pneumothorax, and bilateral proximal renal artery occlusions (Figures 1 and 2) and bilateral adrenal hemorrhages; his other injuries included spinous process fractures from C6–T10, a comminuted left scapular fracture and bilateral acetabular fractures with right SI joint disruption/diastasis. As it had already been approximately 4 h from the time of injury and the patient was still being warmed and resuscitated, it was thought to be most expedient, with the least amount of physiologic insult, to pursue endovascular rather open surgical repair of the renal arteries. Angiography confirmed bilateral proximal intimal dissection with arterial thrombosis. After an unsuccessful attempt to pass the wire across the dissection on the right, the left renal artery was successfully stented with angiographic confirmation of perfusion. Unfortunately, his renal function did not recover. After a 3-week hospitalization and 10 days of inpatient rehabilitation, he had recovered well from his injuries but remains on chronic outpatient hemodialysis. Figure 1.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Blunt renal vascular injuries are rare after abdominal trauma and are reported in only 3–4% of patients with renal trauma (Dinchman and Spirnak 1995; Peterson, 1979). Bilateral blunt renal artery injuries are extremely uncommon with less than 20 reported in the literature (van der Wal et al., 2003). The first case of traumatic renal artery thrombosis was reported in 1861 (Von Recklinghausen, 1861), while the first case of bilateral traumatic renal artery thrombosis was reported over 100 years later, but this patient died despite an attempt to repair his renal injuries (Steiness and Thaysen, 1965). The first case of bilateral traumatic renal artery thrombosis to survive after vascular repair was Morton and Crawford’s case in 1972 (Morton and Crawford, 1972). Coincidentally, that case had a similar presentation to our own with the same mechanism of injury and presenting to the same institution.

The mechanism of injury is stretch of the vascular pedicle, resulting in either renal artery avulsion or intimal tear with dissection causing thrombosis (Clark et al., 1981). Rapid deceleration, such as by high fall, high speed motor vehicle collisions, and pedestrians struck by motor vehicles, are the typical manner of injury (Clark et al., 1981; Morton and Crawford, 1972). CT imaging with intravenous contrast is the preferred modality to evaluate renal injuries in stable patients; specific attention should be concentrated on comparison of the immediate images with the delayed nephrogram images. Vessel avulsion and thrombosis are evident on CT, but an arterial dissection that has not yet caused high-grade stenosis or thrombosis may be difficult to detect, so that angiography may be necessary (Dobrilovic et al., 2001).

Timely identification of this injury is crucial since the warm ischemic time for the kidneys has historically been estimated to be 30–60 min (Spirnak and Resnick, 1987). Successful revascularization has been reported up to 12 h after injury, but these cases with prolonged ischemia were attributed to collateral circulation from adrenal or capsular vessels; while still debated, a 4-h warm ischemic time is considered to be the limit (Long et al., 2004). Although early revascularization is predicted to yield the best results, restoring renal perfusion in less than 4 h does not guarantee a good outcome (Knudson et al., 2000). Surgical mortality rates are 9–20% due to the concomitant abdominal and thoracic injuries and only has long-term success rates of 8.8–30% (Elliott et al., 2007; Hass and Spirnak, 1998; Knudson et al., 2000). Endovascular stenting has been utilized over the last 15 years (Whigham et al., 1995); the National Trauma Data Bank reported that of 517 patients with blunt renal artery injures, 13 patients (3%) were treated endovascularly (Sangthong et al., 2006). Although the published data are based only on individual cases or small case series, and it is not clear that the success rate is improved over open vascular repair, endovascular treatments potentially reduce surgical risks and may become the preferred treatment approach in patients not requiring urgent laparotomy due to other intra-abdominal injuries (Master and McAninch, 2006; Memon and Cheung, 2005).
